comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: I think this is actually Richard Cambrill, a member of NY's high society. However even newspapers of the time were not spelling his family name consistently.

comment.author: 17264356@N00
comment._content: With the water in the background and the purchase ticket sign, plus the obviously stopped vehicle, I'm guessing they are waiting to board a ferry.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: This could be an illustration from The Great Gatsby, eh? A 1915 Massachusetts license plate on what I'm pretty sure is a Stutz Bearcat www.conceptcarz.com/vehicle/z16887/Stutz-Model-4F.aspx

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Seems to be Richard Van Nest Gambrill, son of Richard A. Gambrill and Anna Van Nest Gambrill (his father had died when RVNG was a child), wealthy New Yorkers. His mother's mansion in Newport , R.I., is now a museum. He married Edith D. Blair in 1918, settled in Peapack, New Jersey, became a famous sportsman, particularly with hounds and hunting, and died in 1953. books.google.com/books?id=L9A3AQAAIAAJ&q=richard+v.n.... books.google.com/books?id=pl6JF54vnRIC&pg=PA104&d... see also:
